Literature Review: Mechano-bactericidal (MB) nanopatterns have garnered significant attention in recent years due to their potential to inactivate bacterial cells without the use of harsh chemicals or antibiotics. The mechanism of action of MB surfaces involves the disruption of the bacterial cell envelope, leading to cell lysis and death (1). This process is thought to occur through the creation of mechanical stress on the cell membrane, causing it to rupture and release its contents (2). The use of MB surfaces has been shown to be effective against a wide range of bacteria, including Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, and Salmonella enterica (3, 4, 5).
